Crystal Palace vs Bournemouth live stream and match preview, Saturday 13 May, 3pm BST
Crystal Palace vs Bournemouth live stream and match preview
Looking for a Crystal Palace vs Bournemouth live stream? We've got you covered. Crystal Palace vs Bournemouth is not being shown in the UK. Brit abroad? Use a VPN to watch the Premier League with your subscription from anywhere.
Both Crystal Palace and Bournemouth are safe from the threat of relegation, so the pressure will be off at Selhurst Park.
Roy Hodgson will take charge of his penultimate home game as Palace boss, as the Eagles look to finish as high as possible.
Bournemouth will climb above their upcoming opponents if they triumph in south London.
Kick-off is at 3pm BST. Make sure you know how to watch the Premier League wherever you are.
Team news
Palace will have to make do without Nathan Ferguson and James Tomkins, but James McArthur could be fit enough for a place on the bench.
Bournemouth will be unable to call upon the services of Hamed Traore, Marcus Tavernier, Kieffer Moore, Ryan Fredericks and Junior Stanislas.
Crystal Palace XI: Johnstone; Ward, Andersen, Guehi, Mitchell; Eze, Doucoure, Hughes; Olise, Ayew, Zaha.
Bournemouth XI: Neto; Kelly, Zabarnyi, Mepham, Vina; Rothwell, Lerma; Ouattara, Billing, Christie; Solanke.
Form
Palace were beaten 1-0 by Tottenham last weekend, but they have taken 13 points from a possible 21 under Hodgson.
Bournemouth have amassed 12 points over the same period to leave the relegation dogfight behind.
Referee
Michael Salisbury will be the referee for Crystal Palace vs Bournemouth.
Stadium
Crystal Palace vs Bournemouth will be played at the 25,486-capacity Selhurst Park in London.
Kick-off and channel
Crystal Palace vs Bournemouth kick-off is at 3pm BST on Saturday 13 May in the UK. The game is not being shown in the UK.
In the US, kick-off time is 10am ET / 7am PT. The match will be shown on NBC in the US. See below for international broadcast options.
VPN guide
Use a VPN to watch Premier League football from outside your country
If you’re out of the country for a Premier League fixture, then you won't be able to watch on your domestic streaming service as usual. The broadcaster knows where you are because of your IP address (boo!) and blocks you from watching it. You can use a VPN to get around that, though, without resorting to illegal feeds you’ve found on Reddit.
A Virtual Private Network (VPN), assuming it complies with your broadcaster’s T&Cs, creates a private connection between your device and t'internet, meaning the service can’t work out where you are and will let you watch. And all the info going between is entirely encrypted, anonymous and safe – and that's a result.
